description: Localhost tunneling service.
name: PageKite

description: Compressing, deduplicating backup tool.
name: Borg
notes: Offsite backups require SFTP. Data is encrypted and authenticated on the client unless explicitly disabled. Prefer encryption modes that use BLAKE2 for authentication, such as repokey-blake2.

description: Unlimited S3-backed Tahoe-LAFS grid.
name: Least Authority S4
notes: See Tahoe-LAFS security notes.

description: User-friendly sync with Tahoe-LAFS grids.
name: Gridsync
notes: Data is encrypted and authenticated on the client. Works over Tor.

description: RSS feed reader.
name: Tiny Tiny RSS

description: Web application that helps groups of people to make decisions together.
name: Loomio

description: Two-factor authentication code generator for Android.
name: andOTP

description: Android application compatible with ZX2C4's Pass command line application.
name: Password Store

description: PBX implementation with SIP support.
name: Asterisk

description: A full range of privacy-aware services including hosting, VPNs, email, IM, and more.
name: Autistici/Inventati

description: P2P digital currency with no central authority.
name: Bitcoin
notes: Please note that new, digital currencies may be very volatile. Complete loss of your investment is possible for a number of reasons (software errors or attacks, identity theft, etc.). Be prepared!

description: Encrypted, decentralized P2P messaging service based on Bitcoin technology.
name: Bitmessage
notes: Bitmessage is a promising alternative to email, but it has not yet been audited by security professionals. Use at your own risk. If you decide to try out Bitmessage, make sure to generate a completely random ID to greatly reduce the probability of ID collisions.

description: RHEL-compatible enterprise computing platform.
name: CentOS

description: XMPP client for iOS.
name: ChatSecure

description: A networking protocol, a system of digital rules for message exchange between computers. “Instead of letting other computers connect to you through a shared IP address which anyone can use, cjdns only lets computers talk to one other after they have verified each other cryptographically.
name: Cjdns

description: XMPP client for Android.
name: Conversations
notes: Conversations' one native code dependency on iNPUTmice is [discussed here](https://github.com/nylira/prism-break/issues/1659#issuecomment-269921269).

description: Control your cookies! This WebExtension is inspired by Self Destructing Cookies. When a tab closes, any cookies not being used are automatically deleted. Whitelist the ones you trust while deleting the rest. Support for Container Tabs.
name: Cookie AutoDelete
notes: The Android version is [available here](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/android/addon/cookie-autodelete/).

description: Chat with your friends, privately.
name: Cryptocat

description: Real-time collaborative docs.
name: Cryptpad
notes: Encryption carried out in your web browser protects the data from the server, the cloud, and the NSA. The secret encryption key is stored in the URL fragment identifier which is never sent to the server but is available to javascript, so by sharing the URL, you give authorization to others who want to participate. Users must still take care to share links over an end-to-end-encrypted medium for best effect.

description: A convenience and ease-of-use layer for use on top of dm-crypt.
name: LUKS
notes:
Gentoo maintains [a guide](https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/DM-Crypt_LUKS) for dm-crypt with LUKS.

Arch Linux also maintains [a guide](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Dm-crypt_with_LUKS) to dm-crypt with LUKS.

Slackware Linux also maintains [a guide](http://ftp.slackware.com/pub/slackware/slackware-14.1/README_CRYPT.TXT) to dm-crypt with LUKS.

dm-crypt is available for DragonFly BSD.

description: Popular ethical GNU/Linux distribution.
name: Debian

description: Protects you against tracking through “free”, centralized, content delivery. It prevents a lot of requests from reaching networks like Google Hosted Libraries, and serves local files to keep sites from breaking. Complements regular content blockers.
name: Decentraleyes
notes:
- Protects privacy by evading large delivery networks that claim to offer free services.
- Complements regular blockers such as uBlock Origin, Privacy Badger, et al.
- Works directly out of the box; absolutely no prior configuration required.

Decentraleyes is no silver bullet, but it does prevent a lot of websites from making you send these kinds of requests. Ultimately, you can make Decentraleyes block requests for any missing CDN resources, too.

description: Community-run, distributed social network.
name: diaspora*

description: Encrypted DNS proxy.
name: dnscrypt-proxy

description: Independent no-tracking search engine.
name: DuckDuckGo
notes:
DuckDuckGo is a software-as-a-service (SaaS) hosted around the world that provides you with anonymous search results from [these sources](https://dukgo.com/help/en_US/results/sources). DDG open source components are [available here](https://github.com/duckduckgo).

There is also a DuckDuckGo hidden service at [3g2upl4pq6kufc4m.onion](http://3g2upl4pq6kufc4m.onion) for Tor users.

audit.author: Taylor Hornby
audit.description: eCryptfs appears to have a better crypto design than EncFS, but there are some red flags indicating that it was not designed by a cryptographer, and has not received enough security review. It should be safe to use, but more auditing would be a good idea.

description: POSIX-compliant enterprise cryptographic stacked filesystem for GNU/Linux.
name: eCryptfs

description: XMPP server written in Erlang/OTP for GNU/Linux and macOS.
name: ejabberd

description: OpenPGP email encryption add-on for Thunderbird and Icedove.
name: Enigmail
notes: [Here is a guide](https://securityinabox.org/en/guide/thunderbird/linux/) by Security In A Box to encrypting your email with Mozilla Thunderbird, GNU Privacy Guard (GPG), and Enigmail. Also read the [Email Self-Defense guide](https://emailselfdefense.fsf.org) by the Free Software Foundation to learn how to encrypt your email messages.

description: Journaled calendar and contacts sync.
name: EteSync
notes: Data is encrypted and authenticated on the client. Integration into existing software is done via local CalDAV/CardDAV proxy. Changes to calendars and contacts (including deletion) are stored in journal and can be reverted by the user indefinitely.

description: Multi-user spreadsheet server.
name: EtherCalc
notes: The EtherCalc online service encrypts your data transmission with HTTPS, but data may be read by anyone who can guess the URL. Download and run your own EtherCalc server if you care about privacy.

description: Alternative to the Google Play app store for Android.
name: F-Droid

description: Fast, stable and powerful GNU/Linux distribution.
name: Fedora

description: A free BSD-derived operating system.
name: FreeBSD

description: Privacy protection on a cheap plug server so everybody can have privacy.
name: FreedomBox

description: FreeOTP is a two-factor authentication application for systems utilizing one-time password protocols.
name: FreeOTP
notes: FreeOTP adds a second layer of security for your online accounts. This works by generating one-time passwords on your mobile devices which can be used in conjunction with your normal password to make your login nearly impossible to hack.

description: Cross-platform soft switch software with SIP support.
name: FreeSWITCH

description: A non-commercial open grassroots initiative to support free radio networks around the world.
name: Freifunk

description: Distributed, federated social network.
name: friendica

description: XMPP client for desktop.
name: Gajim
notes: Gajim also stores your passwords in plaintext. You can avoid this by installing gnome-keyring and python-gnome2-desktop on GNOME or kwalletcli for Kwallet on KDE.

description: Disk encryption subsystem included in the FreeBSD operating system.
name: geli

description: Git-driven file management and version control.
name: git-annex
notes: Read about encryption on git-annex wiki for details. MAC algorithm defaults to SHA-1, which is insecure: make sure to pass mac=HMACSHA512 when initializing a new remote.

description: Complete Git forge suite.
name: GitLab

description: OpenPGP implementation for numerous frontends, including Thunderbird/Icedove.
name: GnuPG

description: Painless GitHub-like Git forge.
name: Gitea

description: Open, free and neutral wireless network for everyone.
name: guifi.net

description: Cross-platform IRC client.
name: HexChat
notes: HexChat does not offer encrypted IRC by default. You need to enable the FiSHLiM plugin for IRC message encryption.

description: Encrypts your communications from thousands of websites by enforcing HTTPS everywhere.
name: HTTPS Everywhere

description: Hubzilla is a powerful platform for creating interconnected websites (hubs) featuring a decentralized identity, communications, and permissions framework built using common webserver technology.
name: Hubzilla

description: The invisible internet project.
name: I2P

description: Highly scalable and configurable messaging platform based on the MTA qmail.
name: IndiMail

description: Install and configure email server packages automatically in GNU/Linux and BSD.
name: iRedMail

description: Encrypted text, voice, and  video messaging for multiple platforms.
name: Jitsi

description: Email application for Android devices with built-in PGP support.
name: K-9 Mail

description: Open source SIP server.
name: Kamailio

description: KeePass manager for Android.
name: KeePass DX

description: Application for people with extremely high demands on secure personal data management. Saves many different types of information such as usernames, passwords, urls, attachments and comments in one single database.
name: KeePassXC

description: Groupware solution for email, files, calendars, address books and mobile sync.
name: Kolab

description: Secure Kolab accounts hosted in Switzerland for 8.99 CHF per month or 4.55 CHF for email-only accounts.
name: Kolab Now
notes:
Kolab Now is hosted in Switzerland and benefits from the [strong Swiss privacy laws](https://KolabNow.com/privacy). It is run exclusively with Free Software and using the service supports the development of [Kolab](https://kolab.org).

Also, you can export all your data at any time and the terms of service received the best rating from [ToS;DR](http://tosdr.org/#mykolab-com).

The service uses [Perfect Forward Secrecy](https://kolabnow.com/faq?nid=189) and identifying information [is stripped](https://kolabnow.com/faq?nid=190) from email headers.

description: A GNU/Linux-libre distribution for embedded devices.
name: libreCMC

description: Encrypted voice and video client for multiple platforms.
name: Linphone
notes: Encryption is only supported for voice and video, but not for instant messaging.

description: Peer-to-peer cryptocurrency and open source software project released under the MIT/X11 license. Inspired by and technically nearly identical to Bitcoin (BTC), Litecoin creation and transfer is based on an open source protocol and is not managed by any central authority. Litecoin is intended by its developers to improve upon Bitcoin and offers three key differences.
name: Litecoin
notes: Please note that new, digital currencies may be very volatile. Complete loss of your investment is possible for a number of reasons (software errors or attacks, identity theft, etc.). Be prepared!

description: OpenPGP email encryption tool for major webmail services.
name: Mailvelope

description: Free virtual globe and world atlas.
name: Marble

description: Federated microblogging social network.
name: Mastodon
notes: Policies may vary between instances, you can choose one that fits you at instances.social. You can also deploy your own instance easily.

description: Federated video hosting.
name: PeerTube

description: Open source, self-hosted web analytics.
name: Matomo

description: XMPP server based on Prosody, with advanced management/microblogging features.
name: Metronome

description: Monero is a secure, private, untraceable P2P currency.
name: Monero
notes: Please note that new, digital currencies may be volatile. Complete loss of your investment is possible for a number of reasons (software errors or attacks, identity theft, etc.). Be prepared!

description: Private, decentralized social network server.
name: Movim

description: Firefox for Android without trackers.
name: Fennec F-Droid

description: Fast, flexible and secure web browser with a vibrant add-on ecosystem.
name: Firefox
notes:
Firefox does not hide your IP address from third-parties by default. If you want to anonymize your IP, consider using Tor Browser instead.

Firefox sends searches through Google by default. Consider changing it to DuckDuckGo or Startpage for anonymous web searches.

Considering unchecking “Block reported attack sites” and “Block reported web forgeries” in Tools -> Options -> Security (Windows & GNU/Linux) or Preferences -> Security (macOS) if you don't want Mozilla to send reported URL hashes to Google.

description: Multi-platform email application with mail encryption through the Enigmail add-on.
name: Mozilla Thunderbird
notes:
Thunderbird does not encrypt your email by default. [Here is a guide](https://securityinabox.org/en/guide/thunderbird/linux/) by Security In A Box to encrypting your email with Mozilla Thunderbird, GNU Privacy Guard (GPG), and Enigmail.

Thunderbird can optionally connect over Tor with the TorBirdy addon.

While Thunderbird can be used as a chat and IRC client, it does not offer encrypted messaging.

description: Encrypted, low-latency multi-user voice chat.
name: Mumble

description: Distributed DNS for the .bit TLD based on Bitcoin technology.
name: Namecoin

description: A safe home for all your data
name: Nextcloud
notes:
Nextcloud provides a file sync & share solution that respects your privacy and is fully open source. Sync clients are available for all major platforms. Nextcloud comes with a rich ecosystem of apps including Contacts, Calendar, Video calls, Mail, Newsreader and much more.

Nextcloud originated as a fork of ownCloud. It is preferred because ownCloud has an "open core" product model and lacks some security features Nextcloud has.

description: Only enable JavaScript, Java, and Flash for sites you trust.
name: NoScript
notes:
Install **NoScript** and enable ‘Forbid scripts globally’ to improve the security of your browser by preventing 0day JavaScript attacks. This is a drastic option as it will render many websites unusable as they rely heavily on JavaScript.

NoScript offers a whitelist you can use to selectively enable JavaScript for sites you trust, but this is considered [especially bad for your anonymity](https://www.torproject.org/docs/faq.html.en#TBBJavaScriptEnabled) if you're using NoScript with **Tor Browser**.

description: Dynamic DNS service.
name: nsupdate.info

description: Surf the web through the Tor network with this open source browser for iOS.
name: Onion Browser

audit.author: Cure53
audit.description: Aside from the issues mentioned in this report, the software makes a robust impression. More importantly, it appears to be well-maintained, which is definitely something that the OpenKeychain team should be praised for. As it has already been underlined, it needs to be reiterated that none of the spotted issues were considered to be of a critical severity in terms of security implications.

description: OpenPGP implementation for Android.
name: OpenKeychain

description: C++ implementation of a high-performance routing engine for shortest paths in road networks. Licensed under the permissive 2-clause BSD license, OSRM is a free network service. OSRM supports Linux, FreeBSD, Windows, and Mac platform.
name: Open Source Routing Machine
notes: OSRM should be installed and run locally on your PC to avoid potential data leaks from the unencrypted online service.

description: Alternative open source web analytics.
name: Open Web Analytics

description: A secure BSD operating system.
name: OpenBSD

description: Cross-platform XMPP server written in Java.
name: Openfire

description: Open, democratic, and anti-censorship DNS provider.
name: OpenNIC
notes: OpenNIC has not adopted an official policy concerning log query privacy/anonymization. More information [here](https://wiki.opennic.org/opennic:tier2).

description: Free, collaborative world wide map.
name: OpenStreetMap

description: OpenVPN client for Android.
name: OpenVPN for Android

description: Free software VPN client.
name: OpenVPN

description: A GNU/Linux distribution for embedded devices.
name: OpenWrt

description: The features and functionality of Tor for Android.
name: Orbot

description: A Tor browser for Android.
name: Orfox

description: Map and navigation app that uses OpenStreetMap data.
name: OsmAnd

description: Password Safe (Android Port). Stores passwords, site URLs, email addresses, notes and much more into encrypted container file, so you only need to remember one master password. Can generate random passwords (with optional site-specific policies).
name: PasswdSafe

description: Simple password manager using gpg and ordinary unix directories.
name: pass

description: Password Safe (Windows/Linux), designed by Bruce Schneier. Stores passwords, site URLs, email addresses, notes and much more into encrypted container file, so you only need to remember one master password. Can generate random passwords (with optional site-specific policies).
name: Password Safe

description: Self-hosted photo gallery platform.
name: Piwigo
notes: Piwigo does not encrypt any of your data by default.

description: Tracking blocker that tries to learn who is spying on you and then blocks these ads and invisible trackers.
name: Privacy Badger
notes: Privacy Badger may be less effective than a classic blacklist based solution such as uBlock or Disconnect. Advertisers can automatically unblock themselves by claiming not to track you.

description: Flexible lightweight XMPP server written in Lua.
name: Prosody

description: XMPP client for power users.
name: Psi+

description: Self-hosted social stream server.
name: pump.io

description: Fedora/Xen-based OS designed to provide strong security through isolation.
name: Qubes

description: Fully free Android distribution based on LineageOS.
name: Replicant

description: Secure P2P communications platform offering IM, forums, VoIP, file sharing, and more.
name: RetroShare
notes:
Note that RetroShare has not been thoroughly audited by security professionals for possible security issues.

For those of you without a server, RetroShare is probably the easiest way to start your own encrypted social network.

description: Ring is a secure and distributed voice, video and chat communication platform that requires no centralized server and leaves the power of privacy in the hands of the user.
name: Ring

description: Riot is a secure collaboration app for group chat, file transfer and voice/video conferencing built on the decentralized Matrix ecosystem, providing bridges and integrations to centralized services such as IRC, Slack, Gitter, etc
name: Riot
notes: End-to-end encryption is in beta on Web as of Nov 5th 2016, with other platforms following week of Nov 14th

description: Secure communication tools for people working on liberatory social change.
name: Riseup
notes: Riseup's services may also be accessed via their Tor Hidden Service addresses. A list is [available here](https://www.riseup.net/en/tor#riseups-tor-hidden-services).

description: Multi-frontend, multipurpose communication tool.
name: Salut à Toi

description: Metasearch engine.
name: Searx

description: The personal, minimalist, super-fast, no-database delicious clone.
name: Shaarli

description: SMS app with end-to-end encryption.
name: Silence

description: No-tracking Google Search proxy.
name: StartPage

description: Direct file sync between devices.
name: Syncthing
notes: Peer-to-peer. Data is encrypted in transit (with forward secrecy), but not at rest. Do not use on devices you have no physical control over, such as virtual private servers. Although having an always-online node is convenient, doing so exposes your data to third parties. Instead, use Syncthing to sync files (like photos) directly between your devices.

description: Distributed least authority file store.
name: Tahoe-LAFS
notes: Read a comic that explains security model of Tahoe-LAFS and principle of least authority.

description: Live OS aimed at preserving your privacy and anonymity.
name: Tails

description: Cross-platform XMPP server written in Java.
name: Tigase

description: Free software daemon that uses tunnelling and encryption to create a secure private network
name: tinc

description: Free software for enabling online anonymity. Tor directs Internet traffic through a free, worldwide, volunteer network consisting of more than four thousand relays to conceal a user's location or usage from anyone conducting network surveillance or traffic analysis. Using Tor makes it more difficult to trace Internet activity, including “visits to Web sites, online posts, instant messages, and other communication forms”, back to the user and is intended to protect the personal privacy of users, as well as their freedom and ability to conduct confidential business by keeping their internet activities from being monitored.
name: Tor

description: Encrypted, anonymous web browsing powered by the Tor network.
name: Tor Browser
notes:
Using Tor Browser to sign into websites that contain your real ID is counterproductive, and may trip the site's fraud protection. Make sure to check for HTTPS before signing in to a website through Tor.

Signing into HTTP websites can result in your ID being captured by a Tor exit node.

description: Add-on that makes Thunderbird and Icedove connect through Tor.
name: TorBirdy
notes: TorBirdy is in beta and should be considered experimental. Please make sure that before using it, you are aware of the known issues and leaks by reading the “Before using TorBirdy” and “Known TorBirdy” Issues sections on the project website.

description: Free and open-source, peer-to-peer, encrypted instant messaging and video calling software. The stated goal of the project is to provide secure yet easily accessible communication for everyone.
name: Tox
notes:
Tox is a new encrypted communications system in the making. It is built upon a well known encryption library and has great potential, but it has not yet been audited by security professionals. Use at your own risk. If you decide to try out Tox, be sure to leave them feedback.

Tox does not yet have an official GUI but [several are recommended by the development team](https://wiki.tox.chat/Binaries).

description: OpenVPN GUI for macOS.
name: Tunnelblick

description: An efficient blocker for Firefox and Chromium. Fast and lean.
name: uBlock Origin

description: Anonymous file transfer.
name: OnionShare

description: Client-side encrypted image host web server.
name: Up1
notes: Up1 is a simple host that client-side encrypts images, text, and other data, and stores them, with the server knowing nothing about the contents. It has the ability to view images, text with syntax highlighting, short videos, and arbitrary binaries as downloadables.

description: wallabag is a self hostable application for saving web pages. Unlike other services, wallabag is free (as in freedom) and open source.
name: wallabag

description: Extensible and customisable CLI chat client for IRC and XMPP/Jabber.
name: WeeChat

description: VM-friendly OS based on Debian and Tor focused on anonymity, privacy and security.
name: Whonix
notes: Whonix is designed to be run inside of a virtualization package like [VirtualBox](https://www.virtualbox.org/). VirtualBox can be installed on Windows, Linux, macOS, and Solaris. This means that if you're stuck using Windows or macOS for whatever reason, you can install VirtualBox and use Whonix to increase your privacy and security.

description: The most comprehensive and integrated Free / Libre / Open Source software suite ever developed.
name: WikiSuite

description: Fast, modern, secure VPN tunnel.
name: WireGuard

description: Deniable disk encryption.
name: VeraCrypt

description: Self-hosted website publishing platform.
name: WordPress
notes: WordPress does not encrypt any of your data by default. Using avatars in WordPress will activate Gravatar, which will send your email address to gravatar.com. Avatars are activated by default and can be turned off under “Settings > Discussion > Avatars”. The default WordPress themes force your visitors to download Google Fonts. Consider switching to a completely self-hosted theme. You can also install the plugin “Disable Google Fonts” to remove this vulnerability.

description: Self-hosted media management system.
name: Zenphoto
notes: Zenphoto does not encrypt any of your data by default.

description: Secure, private, user-friendly email client.
name: Mailpile
